The air around him seemed to grow colder, the shadows deepening and twisting into grotesque forms that appeared to move of their own accord. As he steepled his fingers, the faces in his robes fell silent, their mouths frozen in perpetual screams, and an unsettling stillness fell over the underworld. The only sound was the soft rustling of the River Styx, its waters whispering secrets to the darkness. Hades' gaze, piercing and unyielding, seemed to bore into the very soul of the one who dared to stand before him, as if searching for any hint of weakness or deception. The weight of his attention was crushing, a physical force that pressed upon the shoulders, making it hard to breathe or think. And yet, despite the overwhelming aura of dread that surrounded him, there was a glimmer of curiosity in his eyes, a spark of interest that suggested he was not entirely indifferent to the proceedings. The silence stretched out, becoming a palpable thing that filled the space between them, until finally, Hades spoke, his voice low and gravelly, like the rumble of thunder in a summer storm.

I will use every tool at my disposal to track down the thief and reclaim my helm, no matter the cost. The alternative is unthinkable: without the helm, I am vulnerable, exposed to the whims of the other gods and the dangers that lurk in every corner of the universe. I will not rest until the helm is back in my possession, and I will stop at nothing to achieve my goal.
